description: From Middle English gaffe, from Old French gaffe, from Old Occitan gaf (‚Äúhook‚Äù), derivative of gafar (‚Äúto seize‚Äù), from Gothic êå≤êå∞êçÜêçÜ- (gaff-) derived from êå≤êåπêå±êå∞êåΩ (giban, ‚Äúto give‚Äù). Doublet of gaffe.
The underwear sense apparently derives from the idea that the garment tricks or deceives others about the wearer's genitalia.

entries.meaning: A tool consisting of a large metal hook with a handle or pole, especially the one used to pull large fish aboard a boat.
A minor error or faux pas, a gaffe.

examples: The sideshow feat was just a gaff, but the audience was too proud to admit they'd been fooled.

entries.meaning: (nautical) The upper spar used to control a gaff-rigged sail.
(LGBT) A type of tight, panty-like underwear worn to hold the male genitalia tucked backwards and make one's genital region look smooth, as if one had a vulva.

verbs.description: gaff (third-person singular simple present gaffs, present participle gaffing, simple past and past participle gaffed)

entries.meaning: To use a gaff, especially to land a fish.
(transitive) To doctor or modify for deceptive purposes.
examples: When the operator began losing, he gaffed the wheel and then the patron had no chance to win. With his secret device an experienced grifter could stop the wheel at will on any number.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To affix gaffer tape to, or cover with gaffer tape.

description: Perhaps from Old English gafspr«£c (‚Äúbuffoonery, scurrility; blasphemous or ribald speech‚Äù), from Old English gaf (‚Äúbase, vile, lewd‚Äù) + Old English spr«£c (‚Äúlanguage, speech, talk‚Äù). Compare Old English gafettung (‚Äúscoffing, mockery, derision‚Äù).

Unknown. Possibly from Etymology 1, via a sense of ‚Äúa place that will be robbed‚Äù in criminal argot; possibly from Etymology 2, via a sense of "cheap theatre"; possibly from Romani gav (‚Äúvillage‚Äù) (whence German Kaff (‚Äúvillage‚Äù)).

entries.meaning: (Ireland; Britain, especially Manchester, Cockney and Glaswegian; slang) A place of residence.
examples: We're going round to Mike's gaff later to watch the footie.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang, dated) A disreputable, low-end theatre.

examples: She bought a roll of black gaff to tape down the loose cords.
